title: 105_hr189
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure Act" and establishes a commission. The "Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure" is established with 9 members appointed by various officials based on relevant knowledge and expertise. The Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure consists of 9 members appointed based on relevant expertise. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Chairman is elected by the members, and each member serves for the life of the Commission. Security clearances are required for all members. The Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure consists of 9 members appointed based on expertise. Members must apply for security clearances, with expedited processing by the Secretary of Defense. The first meeting must be held within 30 days of all initial appointments. The Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure will conduct investigations. The Commission on Chemical and Biological Warfare Agent Exposure will investigate the presence, locations, and exposure levels of chemical and biological warfare agents in the Persian Gulf theater during the conflict. They will also assess the preparedness of Armed Forces members to recognize and respond to such agents. The Commission will investigate the appropriateness of standards used by the Armed Forces to evaluate low levels of exposure to chemical and biological agents, the adequacy of medical training and procedures for identifying and treating exposure, information provided to members on the presence of agents, and the handling of reports on the use and storage of these weapons. Additionally, they will assess the recordkeeping and reporting procedures of the Department of Defense regarding exposure to these agents. The Commission will investigate the adequacy of Department of Defense training, preparation, detection, and safety procedures concerning exposure to chemical and biological warfare agents. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 2 years, detailing investigation results and recommendations for improving Department of Defense procedures regarding exposure to chemical and biological warfare agents. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, obtain necessary information from government agencies, and issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and evidence related to investigations. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and evidence. If a person refuses to obey a Commission order or subpoena, the Commission can seek a court order for compliance. The Commission also has immunity for witnesses and the authority to contract with government and private agencies for services. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairman with 5 members constituting a quorum. Any member or agent can take authorized actions. Personnel matters are addressed in Section 7. The Commission members are not paid for their service. They receive travel expenses as per regulations. The Commission has a Director appointed by the Chairman who can hire staff and set their pay. The Director and staff are appointed under civil service laws. The service payment is in accordance with chapter 51 and subchapter III of chapter 53, relating to pay rates. SEC. 8. OTHER ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Commission can use postal and printing services, obtain administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services, and procure experts and consultants. SEC. 9. BUDGET ACT COMPLIANCE. Any spending authority authorized by this Act shall be effective only as provided in advance in appropriations Acts. SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will end 60 days after submitting its report.
